newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resid prices mixed, HSFO gains.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resid prices mixed, HSFO gains.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel prices were mixed Thursday in sluggish activity, with relatively firm bunkers boosting high sulphur grades, while low sulphur held steady or lost ground, industry sources said.

"There could be some room to move up, particularly high sulphur, but no one's loading up. They're only buying as they need it," said one cash trader, noting some record cold in the Midwest and East should stir some demand.
In New York Harbor, firm bunkers drove three percent up slightly to near the $14 a barrel level, with 2.2 percent moving up to $14.25 in sympathy, traders said.

NYH 0.3 percent high pour slipped about a quarter to $16.25 on weak utility demand. Despite gains in New York city gate gas prices this week from the cold, traders said HP still remained the more expensive alternative.
NYH physical one percent again was unchanged at $15.25-50, steadied by further gains in crude.
At the U.S. Gulf, three percent notionally was up slightly to $13.25-50, while one percent was still quoted at $15.00-25.
No NYH or USG deals were reported.

On Thursday, New York city gate swing gas prices were unchanged in the low-to-mid $2.40s/mmBtu, or $15.44 a barrel equivalent, bolstered by well-below normal temperatures in the area. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, also held steady in the mid-$1.90s/mmBtu, or $12.29 a barrel.
